summary: This document contains notes from a November 24, 2021 call with Dr. Gail Goodman, an expert in developmental psychology and memory, particularly regarding child sexual abuse (CSA) testimony. The notes detail her academic background, research focus, expert testimony history, and her professional disagreements with memory expert Elizabeth Loftus. The consultation appears to be for a case involving Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Gail Goodman
persons.context: PhD from UCLA specializing in cognitive and memory development in children vs. adults, with extensive research on children's eyewitness testimony about childhood sexual abuse. She has testified as an expert approximately 40 times for both prosecution and defense.

persons.name: Elizabeth Loftus
persons.context: A memory researcher with whom Dr. Goodman has a history of professional disagreement. Loftus's work focuses on memory errors and malleability, while Goodman's focuses on real-world cases of traumatic memory.

persons.name: Ravi Sinha
persons.context: An attorney for whom Dr. Goodman has testified as an expert witness three times. He has worked in DC, Oregon, and at Facebook.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'JE' in the notes. Dr. Goodman states she has read about him online but has not interviewed victims in his case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referred to as 'GM' in the notes. Dr. Goodman states she has read about her online but has not interviewed victims in her case.

events.title: Expert Consultation with Dr. Gail Goodman
events.description: A call was held with developmental psychology expert Dr. Gail Goodman to discuss her research on memory and child sexual abuse testimony, likely in preparation for the Epstein/Maxwell case.

keyFacts: Dr. Gail Goodman's research indicates people are 'quite accurate about sexual abuse even if it happened many years before' and that error rates for false allegations (commission errors) in very young children (3-5 yo) are 'basically 0'.

Goodman disagrees with Elizabeth Loftus's conclusions on memory malleability, arguing Loftus's laboratory studies don't generalize well to real-world traumatic memory, and that misleading questions do not necessarily contaminate memory of abuse.

Goodman has testified as an expert approximately 40 times in federal, state, and family courts, and has worked for both prosecution and defense, though more frequently for prosecution in recent years.
The document confirms the defense in the Epstein/Maxwell case was planning to call Elizabeth Loftus as an expert witness, which Goodman had 'surmised'.
Goodman states she has not interviewed any victims in the Jeffrey Epstein or Ghislaine Maxwell cases, and has only read about them in the press.
